data.title: Tales of the Night (2011)
data.meta_description: Six exotic fables, each unfold in a unique locale, from Tibet, to medieval Europe, an Aztec kingdom, the African plains, and even the Land of the Dead.
data.text:
A solid little animated film which presents two people acting out multiple vignettes in a theater with the aid of an older gentleman. The stories themselves aren't always very gripping and you can't help but want more from the writing (plus only the English dub is on Netflix, and it's not the greatest voice acting by any means), but you can forgive Michel Ocelot because the animation itself is really astonishing. These are worlds you wish you could inhabit, a myriad of vibrant colors and textures which acts as a backdrop to the human characters, who appear only in silhouetted form—an inspired decision, because each setting is what breathes life into its respective vignette.

I don't know if Ocelot's style…

Since his feature film directorial debut (Kirikou and the Sorceress) Michel Ocelot has been, for my money, one of the best directors working in animation and certainly the most criminally underrated. I've seen several of his films by now and continue to be impressed.

Tales of the Night is, as I just learned, a compilation film from episodes of Ocelot's TV show (seems an impossible one to find and you can't easily stream it legally either) Dragons and Princesses. If I needed any more selling (I don't) on watching a show created by him, this film definitely did it.

While not quite as impressive as his 2000 film Princes and Princesses, the 6 stories are still engaging and possess that…
